text:
This is one of the most impressive moments.
of the history of mankind.

For the first time a human being managed to put
one foot somewhere that was not Earth.

American astronauts Neil Armstrong,
Edwin "Buzz" Aldrin and Michael Collins

left for the moon on July 16
1969, only 8 years after Yuri Gagarin,

a Soviet cosmonaut, became
the first man to reach space.

But one thing is to leave Earth and another
is to reach the moon.

Until that time there was no technology to
take people to that distance and bring them
back.
That's why it was a small step for man,
a giant leap for mankind and a decisive fact for the United States in the space
race against the Soviet Union.
But achieving it was not easy.

In the early 60s, the USSR was in
clear advantage: they sent the first satellite to space,

the first living being and
the first man thanks to his chief engineer,
Sergei Korolev

The Americans were terrified
with the idea that space domination
could give the soviets military advantages.
The United States needed an urgent victory over the USSR and President Kennedy
set a very ambitious goal wich was unrealizable for many people.
The Soviets kept moving forward.

In the following years, they sent the first
woman into space and they did the first space walk.

But after the surprising death of Korolev
in 66, the space program of the USSR
lost its way.

And events like the explosion of the N1 rocket
put an end to Soviet ambition
of taking men to the moon.

Meanwhile, the United States needed
a multi-million dollar investment to achieve
its objective.

They needed to create a type of technology for
space traveling and computing that
did not exist at the time.
And they got it with the Apollo program.

The one that would take three American astronauts
to the Moon in the Apollo 11 mission.

After several attempts, NASA built a
rocket that would propel a ship formed by
3 modules

The structure was 111 meters long, weighed
3 million kilos and had so much power
It was like piloting a nuclear bomb.

The great challenge of the mission was to build
a module that could land on the Moon
considering nobody knew what the surface was like.

The module had to be small but at
at the same time it had to transport two astronauts,
computers, equipment, fuel and oxygen.

As if this were not enough, in order to return to Earth,
this module had to propel itself to the
Moon's orbit and meet with the main ship.
The risk was such that Nixon, the US president at that moment, had prepared a speech

in case the astronauts died during the
mission.
But he never needed it.

The first stage of the Apollo 11 journey lasted
three days.

On July 20, Armstrong and Aldrin entered
in the Eagle module to attempt the moon landing.

Inside the command module, Michael Collins
I would continue to orbit the moon, taking pictures
and waiting for them to come back.
But the last moments before moon landing were critical.
Armstrong had to manually pilot the module, which was not planned.
And he only had fuel for 30 more seconds.

The triumphant return of the astronauts after
eight days of mission sent a clear message
of the power of the United States in the middle of the Cold War.
Apollo 11 was followed by six more missions in just 3 years and 10 astronauts returned
to the moon after Armstrong and Aldrin.
but since 1972 nobody has done it again.

Thanks to these missions, there have been great
scientific and technological advances.

Integrated circuits were created, which
allows us to have more compact and powerful
computers.
And the foundations for the birth of the internet were laid.

But beyond science, the legacy
of the Apollo 11 mission was symbolic.

Millions of people saw from their homes
how humanity was able to overcome its
limits.
Mankind had just reached the moon,
What would be the following?
